solutions.title: using-window-function-and-cte
solutions.content:
# Intuition
To solve this problem we need to compare current and previous temperature of two "consecutive dates" 

# Approach
FOR TEMPERATURE:

To achieve this, we need to have the consecutive dates in proper order thats why I have applied "order by recordDate"
Now to compare temperatures, we need both previous and current temperature.
Current temperature we already have, all we need is the previous one which can be achieved by "lag()", Lag function will add a new column having previous temperature beside the current one.
Hence applied a condition in final query to make sure temperature of next date is greater than the previous.


FOR DATE:
Now, to make sure we are comparing temperature of previous date(yesterday), again applied a lag() to recordDate and therefore applied a condition in final query which makes sure the date difference is 1.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
WITH CTE AS(
SELECT id, 
       recordDate, 
       temperature,
       lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate) as pre_temp,
       lag(recordDate) over(order by recordDate) as pre_date
FROM Weather
)
SELECT id as Id 
FROM CTE 
WHERE temperature>pre_temp AND datediff(recordDate,pre_date)=1


```
solutions.code:
```

SELECT id,

       temperature,
       lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate) as pre_temp,
       lag(recordDate) over(order by recordDate) as pre_date
FROM Weather
)
SELECT id as Id 
FROM CTE 
WHERE temperature>pre_temp AND datediff(recordDate,pre_date)=1


```

solutions.title: what-or-why-solution-approach-wow-solution-approach
solutions.content:
# Intuition
To find date, which are having higher temperature then yesterday.
So first observation is that we have to find the relation between same column elements, why leads us to SELF JOIN, now as SELF JOIN uses simple O(n^2) approach( other words two for loops on same table) to match the values on the value we want here we are concerned about two things 
1. Comparision between two date, which can be 1 or -1 let use take 1 only to  understand
2. If difference between two dates is 1 means first date is today and second date is yesterday ( thing what does -1 means then? ) now today temperature should be greater then yesterdays temperature.


# Approach
1. For Comparision or date difference we used DATEDIFF and checked if it is 1 ( you should try -1 also)
2. As differnce is 1 implies first.temp > sec.temp

solutions.title: pandas-sql-easy-rising-temperature-easy
solutions.content:
[see the Accepted Solution](https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/1051882154/)
```
def rising_temperature(weather: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    
    # 1) First, we sort the DataFrame by 'recordDate' in ascending order
    weather.sort_values(by='recordDate', ascending=True, inplace=True)

    # 2) Then, the difference in temperature between consecutive rows are calculated
    weather['temperature_diff'] = weather['temperature'] - weather['temperature'].shift(1)
    
    # 3) At the same time, we calculate the difference in recordDate between consecutive rows
    weather['recordDate_diff'] = weather['recordDate'] - weather['recordDate'].shift(1)

    # 4) then, we select rows where the temperature difference is greater than 0 and the date difference is 1 day
    filter_rising_temperature = weather[(weather['temperature_diff'] > 0) & (weather['recordDate_diff'] == pd.Timedelta(days=1))]['id']
    
    # 5) Finaly, a new Pandas DataFrame from the filtered data above is created
    result_df = pd.DataFrame(filter_rising_temperature)
 
    return result_df
```

**SQL**
[see the Accepted Solution](https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/1061634982/)

```
SELECT weather1.id
FROM Weather weather1 
INNER JOIN Weather weather2
ON weather1.recordDate = DATE_ADD(weather2.recordDate, 
                                  INTERVAL 1 DAY)
WHERE weather1.temperature > weather2.temperature
```

```
-- Select the "id" column from the "Weather" table using the alias "weather1"
SELECT weather1.id

-- Specify that we are performing an INNER JOIN between two instances of the "Weather" table: "weather1" and "weather2"
FROM Weather weather1
INNER JOIN Weather weather2

-- Define the JOIN condition: we are matching records where the "recordDate" in "weather1" matches the "recordDate" in "weather2" 
-- after adding one day to the date from "weather2" using DATE_ADD function
ON weather1.recordDate = DATE_ADD(weather2.recordDate, INTERVAL 1 DAY)

-- Apply a WHERE clause to further filter the results:
-- We are selecting records where the "temperature" in "weather1" is greater than the "temperature" in "weather2"
WHERE weather1.temperature > weather2.temperature
```

solutions.title: solution-with-70-percent-beating-rate
solutions.content:
# Intuition
We need to compare the temperature of each date with the temperature of the previous date (yesterday).
To perform this comparison, we can join the Weather table with itself, creating two instances of the table (w1 and w2).
By joining the tables based on the recordDate column of w1 and the next day's date (DATE_ADD(w2.recordDate, INTERVAL 1 DAY)), we can align the temperatures of consecutive dates for comparison.
The WHERE clause filters the rows where the temperature of the current date (w1.temperature) is higher than the temperature of the previous day (w2.temperature).
Finally, we select the id values from w1 for the matched rows, representing the dates with higher temperatures than their previous dates.

The intuition is to use a self-join operation to align the temperatures of consecutive dates, enabling direct comparison. By checking if the temperature of a date is higher than its previous date, we can identify the desired rows.

# Approach
The query joins the Weather table w1 with itself w2 by matching the recordDate of w1 with the next day's recordDate in w2 using the DATE_ADD function. The WHERE clause filters the rows where the temperature of the current day (w1.temperature) is higher than the temperature of the next day (w2.temperature). Finally, the SELECT statement retrieves the id values from the w1 table for the matched rows.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
Joining two tables typically has a time complexity of O(n * m), where n is the number of rows in the first table and m is the number of rows in the second table.
In this case, assuming the recordDate column is indexed, the join operation can be efficient and reduce the time complexity.
Therefore, the time complexity of the query is typically O(n), where n is the number of rows in the Weather table.

- Space complexity:
The space complexity of the query is minimal since it doesn't require any additional data structures or memory beyond what is used by the database system itself.
It only requires space to store the result set, which in this case is the id values of the rows where the temperature is higher than the next day's temperature.
Therefore, the space complexity is typically O(k), where k is the number of rows in the result set.

# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below
Select w1.id
from Weather w1
join Weather w2 on w1.recordDate = DATE_ADD(w2.recordDate, INTERVAL 1 DAY)
where w1.temperature > w2.temperature
```

# Write your MySQL query statement below
Select w1.id
from Weather w1
join Weather w2 on w1.recordDate = DATE_ADD(w2.recordDate, INTERVAL 1 DAY)
where w1.temperature > w2.temperature
```

solutions.title: mysql-with-explanation
solutions.content:
We need to specify that: 
- difference of days has to be 1 with DATEDIFF(date1, date2) function.
	It calculates like this: (date1-date2). In order to get **datediff=1**, date1 must be the "next" day (higher value). Then date1-date2 = 1
- following the above, also date1 temp has to be higher than date2 (previous day) temp

We specify which is which (date1, date2, date1.temp, date2.temp) by comparing table to itself with two aliases (w, r)

	SELECT w.id FROM Weather w, Weather r
	WHERE DATEDIFF(w.recordDate, r.recordDate) = 1 AND w.temperature > r.temperature

solutions.title: multiple-solutions
solutions.content:
Thing to learn form this problem: comparing dates.

## Solution 1: `DATEDIFF`

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE DATEDIFF(current.recordDate, previous.recordDate) = 1
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```

## Solution 2: `TO_DAYS`

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE TO_DAYS(current.recordDate) - TO_DAYS(previous.recordDate) = 1
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```
or
```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE TO_DAYS(current.recordDate) - 1 = TO_DAYS(previous.recordDate)
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```
or
```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE TO_DAYS(previous.recordDate) + 1 = TO_DAYS(current.recordDate)
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```

## Solution 3: `interval`

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE previous.recordDate + interval 1 day = current.recordDate
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```
or
```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE current.recordDate - interval 1 day = previous.recordDate
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```

## Solution 4: `DATE_ADD` and `interval`

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE DATE_ADD(previous.recordDate, interval 1 day) = current.recordDate
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```

## Solution 5: `DATE_SUB` and `interval`

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT current.id
FROM Weather previous, Weather current
WHERE DATE_SUB(current.recordDate, interval 1 day) = previous.recordDate
AND previous.temperature < current.temperature
```

## And more

And many other options, like using `JOIN`s in previous solutions.

solutions.title: mysql-2-solutions-very-easy-lag-twice-join
solutions.content:
### 🙋🏻‍♀️ Hello, here are my solutions to the problem.
### Please upvote to motivate me post future solutions. HAPPY CODING ❤️
##### Any suggestions and improvements are always welcome.
##### Solution 1: Only join, long, not good 🤦🏻‍♀️
##### ✅ Runtime: 783 ms, faster than 25.50% of MySQL.
```
select
    a.id as id
from
    weather a
join weather b 
on datediff(a.recordDate, b.recordDate) = 1
and a.Temperature > b.Temperature
```
##### Solution 2: Lag twice, faster 🎯
##### ✅ Runtime: 654 ms, faster than 39.98% of MySQL.
```
with q1 as (
select *, 
    lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate) previous_day_temperature,
    lag(recordDate) over(order by recordDate) previous_Date
from Weather
)
select id
from q1
where temperature > previous_day_temperature
and datediff(recordDate, previous_Date) = 1
```
##### If you like the solutions, please upvote 🔼
##### For any questions, or discussions, comment below. 👇️

solutions.title: two-simple-mysql-solutions-join-vs-lag
solutions.content:
**Using Join**
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT a.id
FROM Weather a
JOIN Weather b
WHERE a.temperature > b.temperature AND DATEDIFF(a.recordDate , b.recordDate) = 1;
```

**Using LAG()**
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT id FROM(
    SELECT *,
    LAG(temperature) OVER(ORDER BY recordDate) AS prevT,
    DATEDIFF(recordDate, LAG(recordDate) OVER(ORDER BY recordDate)) AS Delta
    FROM Weather) t
WHERE Delta = 1 AND temperature>prevT
```

)

solutions.title: just-another-approach-still-beats-99
solutions.content:
Not the easiest way ofc but it is interesting how fast it is. Decided to share

```
select b.id from (
    select row_number() over(order by recordDate) i, Id, Temperature, recordDate
    from weather
	) a,
    (select row_number() over(order by recordDate) i, Id, Temperature, recordDate
    from weather
	) b
where a.i + 1 = b.i
and a.Temperature < b.Temperature
and date(a.recordDate) + interval 1 day = date(b.recordDate);
```

solutions.title: use-inner-join-to-date
solutions.content:
```
/* Write your PL/SQL query statement below */
SELECT W1.Id 
FROM Weather W1
INNER JOIN Weather W2 ON W1.RecordDate -1= W2.RecordDate
WHERE W1.Temperature > W2.Temperature;
```
要比较两个温度还是使用内连接，查了网络才知道内连接也可以用计算符的，这个纠结了一下，非日期类型date的格式要比较要使用to_date函数，并且后面日期格式记得是**单引号**，使用双引号会报错
```
ORA-00904: "YYYY-MM-DD": invalid identifier
```
如果这道题是字符串格式的日期，还要先to_date转换
```
/* Write your PL/SQL query statement below ，假设RecoreDate字段是字符串格式，其实用了TO_DATE之后效率反而高了*/
SELECT W1.Id 
FROM Weather W1
INNER JOIN Weather W2 ON TO_DATE(W1.RecordDate,'YYYY-MM-DD') -1= TO_DATE(W2.RecordDate,'YYYY-MM-DD')
WHERE W1.Temperature > W2.Temperature;
```
还有这道题有个小坑，测试阶段输入的数据跟提交阶段输入的数据是不一样的，所以用ID字段取巧是不行了，附上我一开始取巧在测试阶段跑成功但提交失败的代码
```
/* Write your PL/SQL query statement below */
SELECT W1.id 
FROM Weather W1
INNER JOIN Weather W2 ON W2.id +1 = W1.id
WHERE W1.Temperature > W2.Temperature;
```

```

easy-explanation
solutions.content:
**We have to perform inner join since we comparing 2 values in one table**
# How do we get the second value ?
To get the second value we use DATE_ADD Function and save it in  w1.recordDate
# WHATS THIS FUNCTION
The DATE_ADD() function adds a time/date interval to a date and then returns the date.

Syntax
DATE_ADD(date, INTERVAL value addunit)
In our case we need one day

Finally , we compare and get the result based on ther where condition
# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT w1.id FROM Weather w1
JOIN Weather w2
ON w1.recordDate = DATE_ADD(w2.recordDate, INTERVAL 1 DAY)
WHERE w1.temperature > w2.temperature
```

solutions.title: easy-solution-with-line-by-line-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
- The query must retrieve the id of the date when the temperature was more than the previous date.
- A **self-join is done on Weather table with aliases W1 and W2**, with W1 chosen as the table to retrieve the id.
- For this, we use the **DATEDIFF() function** in the Where Clause such that the difference between the date is 1, meaning they are **consecutive dates**.
- Since we retrieve id from W1, we must take care to write** W1 in the first argument of DATEDIFF()**. The correct code with retrieval of id from W2 is commented below in the solution.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
1. In the SELECT statement, we retrieve the id from the chosen alias of the table, here W1. If you retrieve id from W2, consider the commented code.
2. In the FROM statement, we perform a **JOIN operation between the two aliases of Weather table namely W1 and W2**.
3. In the WHERE clause, we use the **DATEDIFF() function** such that the difference between the date is 1, meaning they are consecutive dates. Here, we take **W1 as first argument to the DATEDIFF() function**.

# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT W1.id
FROM Weather as W1 JOIN Weather as W2
WHERE DATEDIFF(W1.RecordDate, W2.RecordDate) = 1 AND W1.Temperature > W2.Temperature;

# SELECT W2.id
# FROM Weather as W1 JOIN Weather as W2
# WHERE DATEDIFF(W2.RecordDate, W1.RecordDate) = 1 AND W2.Temperature > W1.Temperature;
```
# Note 
Please upvote if you find my solution helpful. If you have any doubts, suggestion or want to discuss any solution, comment it. If you wish to discuss other related topics, feel free to message me on LinkedIn, https://leetcode.com/prathams29/

```

solutions.title: mysql-complex-solution-using-window-functions-and-common-table-expressions
solutions.content:
I saw so many people putting out "simple" solutions so I thought why not just put a complex one?
```
WITH cte AS (
    SELECT 
        id, 
        recordDate,
		LAG(recordDate) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS prev_date,
        temperature, 
        LAG(temperature) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS prev_temp
    FROM Weather
)
SELECT id 
FROM cte
WHERE 
    temperature > prev_temp AND
    DATEDIFF(recordDate, prev_date) = 1;
```
So, Here we are using 2 important concepts of SQL:
1. Common Table Expressions or CTEs, and
2. LAG() Window Function

Let's understand both of them, one by one:
* **CTEs:**

Common Table Expressions are used to simplify (quite ironic in this solution though, innit?) complex SQL queries. Now, the question is how does it do it?
So, it basically stores (temporarily only) the result set of a SQL query which we can reference for later use. For eg:
```
-- The CTE "name_of_cte" can be used later, i.e. the result set with field foo can be referenced later in another query as in our solution.
WITH name_of_cte AS (
	SELECT foo FROM bar
)
SELECT foo FROM name_of_cte;
```
It's pretty much just that. Simple, right?

* **LAG() Window Function**

The LAG() function allows us to simply (Oh! I said it again) shift the row data for any particular field by an specific offset value, as sorted by a specified column or set of columns.
Syntax:
`LAG(expression [,offset[,default_value]]) OVER(ORDER BY columns)`

So, in our solution I shifted the recordDate and temperature column as prev_date and prev_temp respectively and refrenced them later (CTE?) to check if:
```
temperature > prev_temp AND DATEDIFF(recordDate, prev_date) = 1;
```

So, I hope you learned something complex today (ofcourse, if you don't already find this simple). Later!
solutions.code:
```
WITH cte AS (
    SELECT 
        id, 
        recordDate,
		LAG(recordDate) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS prev_date,
        temperature, 
        LAG(temperature) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS prev_temp
    FROM Weather
)
SELECT id 
FROM cte
WHERE 
    temperature > prev_temp AND
    DATEDIFF(recordDate, prev_date) = 1;
```
```
-- The CTE "name_of_cte" can be used later, i.e. the result set with field foo can be referenced later in another query as in our solution.
WITH name_of_cte AS (
	SELECT foo FROM bar
)
SELECT foo FROM name_of_cte;
```

```

date is not ascending sorted, and thus if you do not compare with dates but with ID, you may get wrong answer

SELECT a.id
FROM Weather as a,Weather as b
WHERE a.temperature>b.temperature
AND DATEDIFF(a.recordDate,b.recordDate)=1

You must check the datas !
you are just checking the id values .But not comparing the dates.\n

with tmp as (
select id ,RecordDate,Temperature,
LAG (Temperature,1) OVER (ORDER BY RecordDate) AS prev_Temperature,
    LAG (RecordDate,1) OVER (ORDER BY RecordDate) AS prev_RecordDate
from Weather)

select id  from tmp where Temperature>prev_Temperature and (RecordDate-prev_RecordDate)=1

Really interesting approach, except it didn\'t work for me from the get go for some reason, how ever I was able to solve it using `dateDiff(RecordDate, prev_RecordDate)` instead of `(RecordDate-prev_RecordDate)`

WITH yesterday AS (SELECT id,recordDate,temperature,DATE_SUB(recordDate, INTERVAL 1 DAY) AS yesterday
FROM Weather)

SELECT yesterday.id
FROM yesterday LEFT JOIN Weather on yesterday.yesterday = Weather.recordDate
WHERE Weather.temperature IS NOT NULL AND yesterday.temperature > Weather.temperature
the idea is brilliant but why make things complicated? There should be a reasons for doing this.

# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT id
FROM
(
SELECT id, recordDate, temperature AS today_temp, LAG(temperature,1) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS yesterday_temp, LAG(recordDate,1) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS yes_date

FROM Weather
) AS temp_table

WHERE today_temp>yesterday_temp AND DATEDIFF(recordDate,yes_date)=1
Simple and neat query

we need to rearrange this query a little bit as follows 
with CTE as (
select
id,recordDate as [date], temperature as temp,
lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_temp,
lag(recordDate) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_date
from Weather
)

select
id
from CTE
where temp > prev_temp and datediff(day,  prev_date, [date] ) = 1

1)
select a.id
from weather a
inner join weather b
on datediff(day, b.recordDate, a.recordDate) = 1
and a.temperature > b.temperature

2)
with cte as
(select *, 
        lag(temperature)over(order by recordDate) as perviousTemp,
        lag(recordDate)over(order by recordDate) as perviousDate
from weather)
select id from cte where temperature > perviousTemp and datediff(day, perviousDate, recordDate) = 1

This is my code, i think it is very hard ==

SELECT DISTINCT  w2.id
FROM Weather w1
LEFT JOIN Weather w2 ON ABS(DATEDIFF(day,w2.recordDate, w1.recordDate)) = 1
WHERE w2.temperature > w1.temperature and w2.recordDate>w1.recordDate

[@user8224IM](/user8224IM) self join creates every possible combination of columns so that means that you can just filter out the rows where the current temp is greater than yesterday\'s

[@user8224IM](/user8224IM) They have created 2 copies of the same table w1 and w2 and comparing each and every row. 
Selecting only the ids for rows where 
w1.date - w2.date =1 means that w1 is the date of next day to w2 (example: 2nd August - 1st August =1)
AND
w1.Temperature > w2.Temperature means Temperature on Date w1 is greater than Temperature on Date w2. 

so that would get Id with higher temperatures compared to its previous dates (yesterday).
Hope this helps!

    select W1.Id
    from Weather as W1, Weather as W2
    where W1.Date-1 = W2.Date and W1.Temperature> W2.Temperature

it only passed 13/14 cases.

However, when I changed `W1.Date-1` to `sub(W1.Date,1)` in the where clause, it worked. What is fundamental difference?
[@minhphamduy](/minhphamduy) cho m\xECnh h\u1ECFi v\xEC sao ph\u1EA3i c\xF3 ch\u1EEF subquery \u1EDF cu\u1ED1i v?\n

I think you not should do that, use date_add instead
# Write your MySQL query statement below

select id
from (
    select w1.id
    from weather w1, weather w2
    where w1.recordDate= DATE_ADD(w2.recordDate, interval 1 day) and w1.temperature > w2.temperature
) subquery
date is not int
[@michaelniki](/michaelniki)  Thank your for your response, it really helps me.

Its is running successfully but not able to submit!
Select a.id
from 
(Select id, temperature, lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate) as lt,
case when temperature>lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate) then 'High'
else 'Low'
end as 'Status'
from Weather) a
where Status = 'High';
[@avinashkumarjha05](/avinashkumarjha05) the reason is that the test case has 2 dates with a day missing in between.

select x.Id from (
select Id,
       recordDate,
       temperature as temp,
    lag(temperature,1) over(order by recordDate asc) as pre_day_temp
    from weather) x
    where x.temp>x.pre_day_temp;

I am also facing the similar issue
[@avinashkumarjha05](/avinashkumarjha05) test cases are failing because the dates have to be exact previous date. "2000-12-14 |     |2000-12-16"  have a date difference of more than 1 day.

[@avinashkumarjha05](/avinashkumarjha05) I think this is because that we are finding records with only 1 day difference. The records in the test case is using date with 2 days difference, which should not return anything for the output.
mine too ... have u understood why the test case failing?\n

**SELECT a.id
FROM Weather a, Weather b
WHERE datediff(a.recordDate, b.recordDate) = 1
AND a.temperature > b.temperature;**
Wow, what a solution. GOAT. amazing. all the best sandeep.

Hi everyone, I tried the query below. It works when I run MySQL, but it can not work when it is submitted.  Please help me. Thank you.
# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT y.id
FROM Weather x
LEFT JOIN Weather y ON x.Id +1 = y.Id
WHERE x.Temperature < y.Temperature
date is not ascending sorted, and thus if you do not compare with dates but with ID, you may get wrong answer

SELECT a.id
FROM Weather as a,Weather as b
WHERE a.temperature>b.temperature
AND DATEDIFF(a.recordDate,b.recordDate)=1

You must check the datas !
you are just checking the id values .But not comparing the dates.\n

with tmp as (
select id ,RecordDate,Temperature,
LAG (Temperature,1) OVER (ORDER BY RecordDate) AS prev_Temperature,
    LAG (RecordDate,1) OVER (ORDER BY RecordDate) AS prev_RecordDate
from Weather)

select id  from tmp where Temperature>prev_Temperature and (RecordDate-prev_RecordDate)=1

Really interesting approach, except it didn\'t work for me from the get go for some reason, how ever I was able to solve it using `dateDiff(RecordDate, prev_RecordDate)` instead of `(RecordDate-prev_RecordDate)`

WITH yesterday AS (SELECT id,recordDate,temperature,DATE_SUB(recordDate, INTERVAL 1 DAY) AS yesterday
FROM Weather)

SELECT yesterday.id
FROM yesterday LEFT JOIN Weather on yesterday.yesterday = Weather.recordDate
WHERE Weather.temperature IS NOT NULL AND yesterday.temperature > Weather.temperature
the idea is brilliant but why make things complicated? There should be a reasons for doing this.

# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT id
FROM
(
SELECT id, recordDate, temperature AS today_temp, LAG(temperature,1) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS yesterday_temp, LAG(recordDate,1) OVER (ORDER BY recordDate) AS yes_date

FROM Weather
) AS temp_table

WHERE today_temp>yesterday_temp AND DATEDIFF(recordDate,yes_date)=1
Simple and neat query

we need to rearrange this query a little bit as follows 
with CTE as (
select
id,recordDate as [date], temperature as temp,
lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_temp,
lag(recordDate) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_date
from Weather
)

select
id
from CTE
where temp > prev_temp and datediff(day,  prev_date, [date] ) = 1

1)
select a.id
from weather a
inner join weather b
on datediff(day, b.recordDate, a.recordDate) = 1
and a.temperature > b.temperature

2)
with cte as
(select *, 
        lag(temperature)over(order by recordDate) as perviousTemp,
        lag(recordDate)over(order by recordDate) as perviousDate
from weather)
select id from cte where temperature > perviousTemp and datediff(day, perviousDate, recordDate) = 1

This is my code, i think it is very hard ==

SELECT DISTINCT  w2.id
FROM Weather w1
LEFT JOIN Weather w2 ON ABS(DATEDIFF(day,w2.recordDate, w1.recordDate)) = 1
WHERE w2.temperature > w1.temperature and w2.recordDate>w1.recordDate

Okay great.

[@user8224IM](/user8224IM) self join creates every possible combination of columns so that means that you can just filter out the rows where the current temp is greater than yesterday\'s

[@user8224IM](/user8224IM) They have created 2 copies of the same table w1 and w2 and comparing each and every row. 
Selecting only the ids for rows where 
w1.date - w2.date =1 means that w1 is the date of next day to w2 (example: 2nd August - 1st August =1)
AND
w1.Temperature > w2.Temperature means Temperature on Date w1 is greater than Temperature on Date w2. 

so that would get Id with higher temperatures compared to its previous dates (yesterday).
Hope this helps!

Hi all,

I have written down two queries. Kindly let me know which query is optimized query and is efficient? If I am having billions of rows, then which query is good?

# Method 1:
select w1.id from weather as w1
inner join weather as w2
on datediff(w1.recordDate,w2.recordDate) = 1
and w1.temperature > w2.temperature;

# Method 2:
select w1.id from weather as w1
inner join weather as w2
on datediff(w1.recordDate,w2.recordDate) = 1
where w1.temperature > w2.temperature;

'''
select w2.id
from weather w1, weather w2
where w1.temperature < w2.temperature
      and ADDDATE(W1.RecordDate, 1) = W2.RecordDate
'''

`
SELECT d2.Id as Id 
FROM Weather d1, Weather d2 
WHERE d2.Temperature > d1.Temperature 
	AND TRUNC(d2.RecordDate) - TRUNC(d1.RecordDate) = 1
`

| id | recordDate | temperature |
| -- | ------------  | ----------- |
| 1  | 2000-12-14 |     3           |
| 2  | 2000-12-16 |     5           |

In this test my answer is "Id 2". Why is it wrong? He has a higher temperature than the previous day.
I think this is because previous day of 2000-12-16 is 2000-12-15 (it is not in the table) not 2000-12-14. So, your query should  consider a null as previous temperature for the date 2000-12-16.
Same Error

'''

select
id,recordDate as date, temperature as temp,
lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_temp,
lag(recordDate) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_date
from Weather 
)


select
id
from CTE
where temp > prev_temp and (date - prev_date =1 )
'''

**Working Solution:**

with cte as
(select *, lag(temperature,1) over (order by RecordDate) as prev_t,
            lag(RecordDate,1) over (order by RecordDate) as prev_d
from weather)

select id from cte 
where temperature>prev_t
and datediff(RecordDate,prev_d)=1


**Wrong Answer**: *[2] only not the expected [2],[4]*

inner join weather as w2
on datediff(w1.recordDate,w2.recordDate) = 1
and w1.temperature > w2.temperature;

# Method 2:
select w1.id from weather as w1
inner join weather as w2
on datediff(w1.recordDate,w2.recordDate) = 1
where w1.temperature > w2.temperature;

'''
select w2.id
from weather w1, weather w2
where w1.temperature < w2.temperature
      and ADDDATE(W1.RecordDate, 1) = W2.RecordDate
'''

`
SELECT d2.Id as Id 
FROM Weather d1, Weather d2 
WHERE d2.Temperature > d1.Temperature 
	AND TRUNC(d2.RecordDate) - TRUNC(d1.RecordDate) = 1
`

[[來學資料庫] LeetCode DataBase SQL 觀念解析(07): #197. Rising Temperature](https://medium.com/@s9811219/rising-temperature-leetcode-4cde8ad1e681)

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/s9811219/image_1574246339.png)
If use "full join" or "full outer join" instead of "join", it will throw a runtime error. Anybody knows why?
Mysql doesn\'t have a full join.
I learn for mysql just few days, my solution was as following:\nselect t1.Id from Weather as t1, Weather as t2 where datediff(t1.Date, t2.Date)=1 and (t1.Temperature - t2.Temperature) > 0;

| id | recordDate | temperature |
| -- | ------------  | ----------- |
| 1  | 2000-12-14 |     3           |
| 2  | 2000-12-16 |     5           |

In this test my answer is "Id 2". Why is it wrong? He has a higher temperature than the previous day.
I think this is because previous day of 2000-12-16 is 2000-12-15 (it is not in the table) not 2000-12-14. So, your query should  consider a null as previous temperature for the date 2000-12-16.
Same Error

'''
with CTE as (
select
id,recordDate as date, temperature as temp,
lag(temperature) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_temp,
lag(recordDate) over(order by recordDate,id) as prev_date
from Weather 
)


select
id
from CTE
where temp > prev_temp and (date - prev_date =1 )
'''

**Working Solution:**

with cte as
(select *, lag(temperature,1) over (order by RecordDate) as prev_t,
            lag(RecordDate,1) over (order by RecordDate) as prev_d
from weather)

select id from cte 
where temperature>prev_t
and datediff(RecordDate,prev_d)=1


**Wrong Answer**: *[2] only not the expected [2],[4]*

with cte as
(select *, lead(temperature,1) over (order by RecordDate) as n_t,
            lead(RecordDate,1) over (order by RecordDate) as n_d
from weather)

select id from cte 
where temperature>n_t

Hey can someone help pls, i use pandas and don't know what's wrong with my code  
 
V1
def rising_temperature(weather: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    weather["recordDate"] = pd.to_datetime(weather["recordDate"])
    weather["temperature_1"] = weather["temperature"].shift(1)
    output = weather[abs(weather["temperature"]) > abs(weather["temperature_1"])]
    return pd.DataFrame(output["id"])

V2
def rising_temperature(weather: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    weather["recordDate"] = pd.to_datetime(weather["recordDate"])
    weather["recordDate1"] = weather["recordDate"] - pd.DateOffset(days=1)
    weather["temperature1"] = weather["temperature"].shift(1)
    output = weather[(weather["recordDate"] - weather["recordDate1"] == pd.Timedelta(days=1)) & (abs(weather["temperature"]) > abs(weather["temperature1"]))]
    return pd.DataFrame(output["id"])

My code is pointed as correct when I run it, however it's not able to be submitted until MySQL is changed to Oracle. 
Don't understand the reason, but lots of people here reported similar issues.

So try to shift from MySQL to Oracle. May be it helps in such a situation.
FROM Weather AS w1, Weather AS w2\nWHERE DATEDIFF(w1.recordDate,w2.recordDate)=1\nAND w1.temperature> W2.temperature

Best and easy way using Date _add and self join
Select curr.id
from weather Curr
inner join weather pre
on curr.recordDate = date_add(pre.recordDate, interval 1 day)
and curr.temperature > pre.temperature;

Accepted but cant submit

select Id
from Weather w
order by w.temperature desc
limit 2

I have tried two approaches, surprising thing is Approach 2 has faster execution time than Approach 1, even though Approach 1 is accessing underlying Weather table only once. It does imply Lag and over maybe slower.

Approach 1:
# Write your MySQL query statement below
with temp as
(
    select id, RecordDate, Temperature,
    lag(Temperature,1) over (order by RecordDate) as previousTemperature,
    lag(RecordDate,1) over (order by RecordDate) as PreviousDate
    from Weather
)
Select id from Temp where Temperature > PreviousTemperature and and datediff(RecordDate,PreviousDate) =1

Approach 2:
# Write your MySQL query statement below
Select
currentDay.id
from
(Select id, recordDate, temperature from Weather) as prevDay
inner join
(Select id, date_sub(recordDate, Interval 1 Day) as recordDate, temperature from Weather)  as currentDay
on 
prevDay.recordDate = currentDay.recordDate
where prevDay.temperature < currentDay.temperature

Oracle SQL:

WITH cte1 as (select id, recorddate, temperature, lag(temperature) over (order by recorddate) as previous_day_temp from weather)
select id from cte1 
where temperature > previous_day_temp
Order by id asc;
select id from (select *, lag(temperature, 1) over(order by recordDate asc) as lagtemp from weather) as sub2 where (temperature - lagtemp) > 0

can anyone explain, why this code dosn't pass 5 test case?

select id from weather 
except
select id from weather 
where 
temperature < (select temperature from weather limit 1 offset 1);

i don't understand
ok, i\'m little stpd. don\'t know why, but i thought this works like cycle, but it always compare value with second row

Haven't seen anyone use this method:
SELECT id
FROM Weather w1
WHERE temperature > (SELECT temperature from Weather w2 WHERE w1.id = w2.id + 1)
Is there something wrong with it? it worked for me.

it only works if you always insured the ids are sequential and there are no deleted rows, a simple example, think about a glitch that has removed a row of the id `3`, now the dependent next row will not be able to get the correct result hence `4` needs to know what `3` has but it doesn\'t exist, if we really have a higher temp on either we can\'t tell anymore.

FROM Weather w1
WHERE temperature > (SELECT temperature from Weather w2 WHERE w1.id = w2.id + 1)

FROM Weather)

WHERE temperature - prev_temp  > 0

why this does not work?

 `# Write your MySQL query statement below
select w1.id 
from Weather as w1
where exists (
    select w2.id 
    from Weather as w2
    where YEAR(w1.recordDate)=YEAR(w2.recordDate) and MONTH(w1.recordDate)=MONTH(w2.recordDate) and DAY(w1.recordDate)-DAY(w2.recordDate)=1 and w1.temperature > w2.temperature
)`

solved using windows functions  
select id
from 
(select*,
lag(temperature)over(order by recordDate) as prev_temp
from Weather ) as tbl
where temperature > prev_temp
Most fastest way : \n`Select w2.id from Weather w1, Weather w2  where w1.temperature < w2.temperature and w2.recordDate = DATEADD(day, 1, w1.recordDate);`
Fastest way :- MS SQL Server\n\n `Select w2.id from Weather w1, Weather w2  where w1.temperature < w2.temperature and w2.recordDate = DATEADD(day, 1, w1.recordDate);`
what should be approach for problem if data given is not for consecutive dates.

Why does this doesnt work?
```
SELECT w1.id AS Id
FROM Weather w1 
LEFT JOIN Weather w2
ON w1.recordDate = w2.recordDate + 1
WHERE w1.temperature > w2.temperature;
```

And this does?
```
SELECT w1.id AS Id
FROM Weather w1 
LEFT JOIN Weather w2
ON DATEDIFF (w1.recordDate, w2.recordDate) = 1
WHERE w1.temperature > w2.temperature ;
```

Based on the `Weather` table, we can see that both the `recordDate` and `id` are in order but use of `recordDate` will likely be a better option. ## Approach Solution 1: - Using the `LAG()` function allows us to get the preceding value - Integrate this with the `WITH` query to generate a new table - Query for `Id` that has higher temperature than their precedence, and ensuring the difference in day is just 1 with `DATEDIFF()` function Solution 2: - Extract the `Id` by comparing 2 same `Weather` tables as today `tdy` and yesterday `ytd` - Query WHERE difference of day is 1 with `DATEDIFF()` - AND `tdy.temperature` is higher than `ytd.temperature`

title: Serialize and Deserialize Binary Tree
question_content:
Serialization is the process of converting a data structure or object into a sequence of bits so that it can be stored in a file or memory buffer, or transmitted across a network connection link to be reconstructed later in the same or another computer environment.

Design an algorithm to serialize and deserialize a binary tree. There is no restriction on how your serialization/deserialization algorithm should work. You just need to ensure that a binary tree can be serialized to a string and this string can be deserialized to the original tree structure.

Clarification: The input/output format is the same as how LeetCode serializes a binary tree. You do not necessarily need to follow this format, so please be creative and come up with different approaches yourself.

 

Example 1:

Input: root = [1,2,3,null,null,4,5]
Output: [1,2,3,null,null,4,5]

Example 2:

Input: root = []
Output: []

 

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [0, 104].
  • -1000 <= Node.val <= 1000

solutions.content:
```
class Codec:
    def serialize(self, root):
        # take care of base cases
        # if a node is empty, add 'x' to string
        # you can set 'x' to any mark as you want
        if not root: return 'x'
        # preoder(Root->left->right)
        # ex,
        #     1
        #    / \
        #   2   3
        #      / \
        #     4   5 
        # 
        # return (1, (2, 'x', 'x'), (3, (4, 'x', 'x'), (5, 'x', 'x')))
        # if you look at the return statement very closely, it is actually very intuitive
        # for value 1, you have 2 as left child and 3 as right child
        # for value 2, you have 'x'(None) as left child and 'x'(None) as right child which indicates it is a leaf node
        return root.val, self.serialize(root.left), self.serialize(root.right)

    def deserialize(self, data):
        #######################INTUITION#########################
        # The initial data string will be something like below:
        # (1, (2, 'x', 'x'), (3, (4, 'x', 'x'), (5, 'x', 'x')))
        # if you loop through string: 
        # 1                                 -> this is node value
        # (2, 'x', 'x')                     -> this is node left
        # (3, (4, 'x', 'x'), (5, 'x', 'x')) -> this is node right
        ########################################################
        # always take care of base case: if the node's value is 'x' then return None
        if data[0] == 'x': return None
        # create new treenode for node value
        node = TreeNode(data[0])
        # do the recursive to unpack string value
        node.left = self.deserialize(data[1])
        node.right = self.deserialize(data[2])
        # return the new TreeNode that we just created
        return node
```

I tried to maintain the coding style as similar as possible to above solution.
```
class Codec:
    def serialize(self, root):
        if not root: return 'x'
        return ','.join([str(root.val), self.serialize(root.left), self.serialize(root.right)])

    def deserialize(self, data):
		# The reason I use self.data in the deserialize is, data stream will be consumed  as we build left side of Tree
		# by the time when the right side is building up, we need to hold what is left over.
		# Therefore, self.data is a global value, right side will use what is left over after tree is partially built
        self.data = data
        if self.data[0] == 'x': return None
        node = TreeNode(self.data[:self.data.find(',')]) 
        node.left = self.deserialize(self.data[self.data.find(',')+1:])
        node.right = self.deserialize(self.data[self.data.find(',')+1:])
        return node
```

solutions.content:
**✔️ Solution 1: DFS - Serialize and Deserialize in Pre Order Traversal**

<iframe src="https://leetcode.com/playground/R7vVdhU8/shared" frameBorder="0" width="100%" height="750"></iframe>

**Complexity**
- Time: `O(N)`, where `N <= 10^4` is number of nodes in the Binary Tree.
- Space: `O(N)`

---

**✔️ Solution 2: BFS**
```python
class Codec:
    def serialize(self, root):
        if root == None: return "#"
        bfs = deque([root])
        ans = []
        while bfs:
            curr = bfs.popleft()
            if curr == None:
                ans.append("#")
            else:
                ans.append(str(curr.val))
                bfs.append(curr.left)
                bfs.append(curr.right)
        return ",".join(ans)

    def deserialize(self, data):
        def createNode(strVal):
            if strVal == "#": return None
            return TreeNode(int(strVal))

        if data == "#": return None
        strs = data.split(",")
        root = createNode(strs[0])
        i = 1
        bfs = deque([root])
        while bfs:
            curr = bfs.popleft()
            curr.left = createNode(strs[i])
            curr.right = createNode(strs[i+1])
            i += 2

            if curr.left != None:
                bfs.append(curr.left)
            if curr.right != None:
                bfs.append(curr.right)

        return root
```
**Complexity**
- Time: `O(N)`, where `N <= 10^4` is number of nodes in the Binary Tree.
- Space: `O(N)`

# Definition for a binary tree node.
    # class TreeNode(object):
    #     def __init__(self, x):
    #         self.val = x
    #         self.left = None
    #         self.right = None
    
    from collections import deque
    
    class Codec:
    
        def serialize(self, root):
            string = ""
            queue = deque([root])
            while queue:
                cur = queue.popleft()
                if not cur:
                    string += ",None"
                    continue
                else:
                    string += "," + str(cur.val)
                    queue.append(cur.left)
                    queue.append(cur.right)
            return string
            
        def deserialize(self, data):
            data = deque(data.split(","))
            _, val = data.popleft(), data.popleft()
            root = None if val == "None" else TreeNode(int(val))
            queue = deque([root])
            while queue:
                cur = queue.popleft()
                if cur:
                    a, b = data.popleft(), data.popleft()
                    cur.left = TreeNode(int(a)) if a != "None" else None
                    cur.right = TreeNode(int(b)) if b != "None" else None
                    queue.append(cur.left)
                    queue.append(cur.right)
            return root
    
    # Your Codec object will be instantiated and called as such:
    # codec = Codec()
    # codec.deserialize(codec.serialize(root))

solutions.content:
```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        # use level order traversal to match LeetCode's serialization format
        flat_bt = []
        queue = collections.deque([root])
        while queue:
            node = queue.pop()
            if node:
                flat_bt.append(str(node.val))
                queue.appendleft(node.left)
                queue.appendleft(node.right)
            else:
                # you can use any char to represent null
                # empty string means test for a non-null node is simply: flat_bt[i]
                flat_bt.append('')
        return ','.join(flat_bt)
    # time:  O(n)
    # space: O(n)

    def deserialize(self, data):
        if not data:
            return
        flat_bt = data.split(',')
        ans = TreeNode(flat_bt[0])
        queue = collections.deque([ans])
        i = 1
        # when you pop a node, its children will be at i and i+1
        while queue:
            node = queue.pop()
            if i < len(flat_bt) and flat_bt[i]:
                node.left = TreeNode(int(flat_bt[i]))
                queue.appendleft(node.left)
            i += 1
            if i < len(flat_bt) and flat_bt[i]:
                node.right = TreeNode(int(flat_bt[i]))
                queue.appendleft(node.right)
            i += 1
        return ans
    # time:  O(n)
    # space: O(n)
```

solutions.title: python-solution
solutions.content:
Method 1: Use preorder traversal to encode. Time complexity for both `serialize` and `deserialize` are `O(n)`, where `n` is the number of nodes in the binary tree.

Implementation 1: recursive `deserialize`.
```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        def dfs(root):
            if not root:
                res.append("None,")
                return 
            res.append(str(root.val)+",")
            dfs(root.left)
            dfs(root.right)
            
        res = []
        dfs(root)
        return "".join(res)
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        def helper(q):
            if q[0] == "None":
                q.popleft()
                return
            root = TreeNode(q.popleft())
            l = helper(q)
            r = helper(q)
            root.left = l
            root.right = r
            return root
        
        lst = data.split(",")
        q = collections.deque(lst)
        return helper(q)
```
Implementation 2: iterative `deserialize`.
```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        def dfs(root):
            if not root:
                res.append("None,")
                return
            res.append(str(root.val)+",")
            dfs(root.left)
            dfs(root.right)
        res = []
        dfs(root)
        return "".join(res)
       
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        q = collections.deque(data.split(","))
        q.pop()
        stack = []
        head = None
        right = False
        while q:
            u = q.popleft()
            if not head:
                if u == "None":
                    return
                head = TreeNode(u)
                stack.append(head)
                trav = head
            else:
                if u != "None":
                    node = TreeNode(u)
                    if not right:
                        trav.left = node
                    else:
                        trav.right = node
                        right = False
                    stack.append(node)
                    trav = node
                else:
                    if stack:
                        trav = stack.pop()
                        right = True
        if head:
            return head
```

Method 2: Use level order traversal (BFS) to encode. Time complexity for both `serialize` and `deserialize` are `O(n)`, where `n` is the number of nodes in the binary tree.

```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        if not root:
            return ""
        q = collections.deque([root])
        res = [str(root.val)+","]
        while q:
            u = q.popleft()
            if u.left:
                res.append(str(u.left.val)+",")
                q.append(u.left)
            else:
                res.append("None,")
            if u.right:
                res.append(str(u.right.val)+",")
                q.append(u.right)
            else:
                res.append("None,")
        return "".join(res)
                     

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """

        lst.pop()
        q = collections.deque(lst)
        head = None
        nodeq = collections.deque([])
        while q:
            if not head:
                u = q.popleft()
                head = TreeNode(u)
                nodeq.appendleft(head)
            else:
                l = q.popleft()
                r = q.popleft()
                l = TreeNode(l) if l != "None" else None
                r = TreeNode(r) if r != "None" else None
                tmp = nodeq.popleft()
                if l:
                    tmp.left = l
                    nodeq.append(l)
                if r:
                    tmp.right = r
                    nodeq.append(r)
        return head

class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):

        if not root:

        q = collections.deque([root])
        res = [str(root.val)+","]

            u = q.popleft()
            if u.left:
                res.append(str(u.left.val)+",")
                q.append(u.left)
            else:
                res.append("None,")
            if u.right:
                res.append(str(u.right.val)+",")
                q.append(u.right)
            else:

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode

        lst = data.split(",")
        lst.pop()
        q = collections.deque(lst)
        head = None
        nodeq = collections.deque([])
        while q:
            if not head:
                u = q.popleft()
                head = TreeNode(u)
                nodeq.appendleft(head)

    def serialize(self, root):
        if not root: return []
        data = []
        # use deque for fast popleft / bfs traversal 
        queue = deque([root])
        while queue:
            node = queue.popleft()
            if node: 
                data.append(node.val)
                queue.append(node.left)
                queue.append(node.right)
            else:
                data.append('#')
        #remove trailing '#'
        while data[-1] == '#':
            data.pop()
        return data
    
    def deserialize(self, data):
        if not data: return []
        root = TreeNode(data[0])
        i = 1
        queue = deque([root])
        while queue and i <= len(data) -1:
            node = queue.popleft()
            if data[i] != '#':
                left = TreeNode(data[i])
                node.left = left
                queue.append(left)
            i += 1
            if i > len(data)-1:
                break
            if data[i] != '#':
                right = TreeNode(data[i])
                node.right = right
                queue.append(right)
            i += 1
        return root       
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
The Codec class provides methods for serializing and deserializing a binary tree. The intuition behind this code is that it encodes the structure of a binary tree into a string that can be easily transmitted or stored, and then decodes the string to reconstruct the original binary tree. This can be useful in situations where a binary tree needs to be transmitted over a network or stored in a file.
# Approach
The serialize method serializes a binary tree by recursively calling itself on the left and right children of each node, and concatenating the results into a string with the value of the current node in the middle. If a node is None, it is represented by the string "x". The deserialize method deserializes a binary tree by first checking if the input string is equal to "x", in which case it returns None. Otherwise, it parses the string to obtain the value of the current node, the string representation of its left child, and the string representation of its right child. It then recursively calls itself on the left and right child strings to obtain the corresponding binary trees, and returns a new TreeNode object with the current value and left and right children.


# Complexity
- Time complexity:
The time complexity of the serialize method is O(n), where n is the number of nodes in the binary tree, since it visits each node exactly once. The time complexity of the deserialize method is also O(n), since it needs to parse the input string and create a new TreeNode object for each node in the binary tree.


- Space complexity:
The space complexity of both methods is O(n), since they both use recursion and may need to store information about all nodes in the binary tree on the call stack. In the serialize method, the maximum depth of the call stack is equal to the height of the binary tree, which is O(log n) in the best case and O(n) in the worst case. In the deserialize method, the call stack depth is also O(log n) in the best case, but can be as high as O(n) in the worst case if the binary tree is degenerate. Additionally, the deserialize method creates a new TreeNode object for each node in the binary tree, which requires O(n) space in the worst case.




# Code
```
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode(object):
#     def __init__(self, x):
#         self.val = x
#         self.left = None
#         self.right = None

class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        if root==None:
            return "x"
        return "["+str(root.val)+","+self.serialize(root.left)+","+self.serialize(root.right)+"]"
        
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        if data=="x":
            return None
        else:
            #val
            val=int(data[1:data.find(",")])

            #left
            leftstart=data.index(',')+1
            if data[leftstart]=="x":
                leftend=leftstart+1
            else:
                leftend=0
                co=1
                for i in range(leftstart+1,len(data)):
                    if co==0:
                        leftend=i
                        break
                    elif data[i]=="[":
                        co+=1
                    elif data[i]=="]":
                        co-=1
            #right
            if data[leftend+1]=="x":
                right=None
            else:
                r=data[leftend+1:len(data)-1]  
                right=self.deserialize(r)
             
        return TreeNode(val,self.deserialize(data[leftstart:leftend]),right)
        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
This code is an implementation of a binary tree serialization and deserialization algorithm.

The serialize method takes a binary tree root node as input and returns a string representation of the tree. It uses a pre-order traversal to traverse the tree and add each node's value to a list s. If a node is None, it appends the character 'n' to the list. Finally, the list is joined into a string using a space separator and returned.

The deserialize method takes a string representation of a binary tree as input and returns the corresponding binary tree root node. It first splits the input string into a list of values using space as a delimiter. It uses a recursive preorder helper function to build the tree. The preorder function recursively constructs the tree by popping values from the list and creating a node for each value. If the popped value is the character 'n', it returns None since the node has no children. Otherwise, it creates a node with the popped value as its value, and recursively constructs its left and right subtrees by calling the preorder function again. Finally, it returns the root node of the constructed tree.

Overall, this implementation uses a simple and efficient approach to serialize and deserialize binary trees using a pre-order traversal.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
95.90%

- Space complexity:
61.53%

# Code
```
class Codec:
  def serialize(self, root: 'TreeNode') -> str:
    """Encodes a tree to a single string."""
    s = []

    def preorder(root: 'TreeNode') -> None:
      if not root:
        s.append('n')
        return

      s.append(str(root.val))
      preorder(root.left)
      preorder(root.right)

    preorder(root)
    return ' '.join(s)

  def deserialize(self, data: str) -> 'TreeNode':
    """Decodes your encoded data to tree."""
    q = collections.deque(data.split())

    def preorder() -> 'TreeNode':
      s = q.popleft()
      if s == 'n':
        return None

      root = TreeNode(s)
      root.left = preorder()
      root.right = preorder()
      return root

    return preorder()

```

solutions.content:
Great question that could be of great use!

Use **BFS** to solve!

Use **'#'** to mark a None node.
When deserialize, we use a variable **"isLeftChild"** to decide when we should move to next node.

**Time:** O(n)
**Space:** O(n)

```
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode(object):
#     def __init__(self, x):
#         self.val = x
#         self.left = None
#         self.right = None

class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        if not root:
            return ''
        
        queue = [root]
        index = 0
        while index < len(queue):
            if queue[index]:
                queue.append(queue[index].left)
                queue.append(queue[index].right)
            index += 1
        
        return ','.join([
            str(node.val) if node else '#'
            for node in queue
        ])

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        if data == '':
            return None
        
        vals = data.split(',')
        root = TreeNode(int(vals[0]))
        queue = [root]
        isLeftChild = True
        index = 0
        for val in vals[1:]:
            if val is not '#':
                node = TreeNode(int(val))
                if isLeftChild:
                    queue[index].left = node
                else:
                    queue[index].right = node
                queue.append(node)
            if not isLeftChild:
                index += 1
            isLeftChild = not isLeftChild
        
        return root
```

solutions.content:
The "naive" solution is to traverse the tree, and encode empty locations with "None" or some special sign.

This leads to having unecessarily long bits of data, which isn't the best if we want to be efficient. we can do better.

# Intuition

There is a concept of flattening a binary tree into an array, let's take the following example:

```
  	   1
    /    \
   2      3 
  / \    / \
 4   5  6   7 
```

We can represent that tree with an array: `[1,2,3,4,5,6,7]`

`1` is the root - index 0 in the array

To get to 1's children, we access `index*2+1` for left child, and `index*2+2` for right child. We can access all node's children the same way.

So we'll use that insight to encode/serialize the data.

## What about deserialize?

Whenever we need to deserialize the string, first we create a hash map of `index -> value.`

Now we know that the root starts at index 0, and we also know how to access the children, as discussed above, so we will simply check whether the child index exists or not. If it does, we create the node and continue to the children recursively. If the index doesn't exist in the encoded string, we return null.

# Implementation
Read the code, it's super easy to understand.

I've encoded the index -> value as {index}#{value}. For example for index 0, with value 2: `"0#2"`

# Code
```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        if not root: return ""
        
        encoded_format = []
        q = deque([(root, 0)])
        
        while q:
            node, index = q.popleft()
            encoded_format.append(f"{index}#{node.val}")
            
            if node.left: q.append((node.left, index*2+1))
            if node.right: q.append((node.right, index*2+2))
        
        serialized_string = ",".join(encoded_format)
        return serialized_string
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        index_to_value = {int(x.split("#")[0]): int(x.split("#")[1]) for x in data.split(",")}
        return self.build_tree(index_to_value, 0)
        
    
    def build_tree(self, index_to_value: dict[int, int], index: int):
        if index not in index_to_value: return None
        
        node = TreeNode(index_to_value[index])
        node.left = self.build_tree(index_to_value, index*2+1)
        node.right = self.build_tree(index_to_value, index*2+2)
        return node
        
```


# Final notes
It doesn't matter what traversal algorithm you use to encode the tree.

I used BFS, but one might also use DFS and track the index of the node that is being processed.

# Appendix
Attaching the classic preorder DFS solution, written by me.

```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        if not root: return ""
        encode = []
        
        def pre_order(node):
            if not node:
                encode.append("None")
                return
            
            encode.append(str(node.val))
            pre_order(node.left)
            pre_order(node.right)
            
        pre_order(root)
        encoded_string = ",".join(encode)
        return encoded_string
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        if not data: return None
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        encoded = data.split(",")
        n = len(encoded)
        
        def build_tree(index):
            if index >= n:  return None, index
            if encoded[index] == "None":  return None, index
            
            node = TreeNode(int(encoded[index]))
            left_tree, last_index = build_tree(index + 1)
            node.left = left_tree
            
            right_tree, last_index = build_tree(last_index + 1)
            node.right = right_tree
            
            return node, last_index
            
            
        return build_tree(0)[0]
```

```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        if not root: return ""
        
        encoded_format = []
        q = deque([(root, 0)])
        
        while q:
            node, index = q.popleft()
            encoded_format.append(f"{index}#{node.val}")
            
            if node.left: q.append((node.left, index*2+1))
            if node.right: q.append((node.right, index*2+2))
        
        serialized_string = ",".join(encoded_format)
        return serialized_string
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        index_to_value = {int(x.split("#")[0]): int(x.split("#")[1]) for x in data.split(",")}
        return self.build_tree(index_to_value, 0)
        
    
    def build_tree(self, index_to_value: dict[int, int], index: int):
        if index not in index_to_value: return None
        
        node = TreeNode(index_to_value[index])
        node.left = self.build_tree(index_to_value, index*2+1)
        node.right = self.build_tree(index_to_value, index*2+2)
        return node

        q=queue.Queue()

        s=s.split(",")

solutions.content:
I gave a shot at this problem. Even though it is obvious that we are expected to explore the tree and find a structure which encode the tree and be transformed back into a binary tree, there's a loophole in this problem and it comes from the way the `Codec` is instantiated and called. In the solution, there is the following comment:
```
# Your Codec object will be instantiated and called as such:
# ser = Codec()
# deser = Codec()
# ans = deser.deserialize(ser.serialize(root))
```
No check is being made on the outputs/inputs types. So basically, the solution:
```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        return root
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        return data
```
Works more than well and be both faster and less memory-consumer than >99% of Python3 implementations.

```
class Codec:
    def serialize(self, root):
        ans = []
        def dfs(node):
            if node is None:
                ans.append('#')
                return
            ans.append(node.val)
            dfs(node.left)
            dfs(node.right)
        dfs(root)
        return ans
    def deserialize(self, data):
        data = collections.deque(data)
        def dfs():
            if data:
                i = data.popleft()
            else: return None
            if i is '#': return None
            node = TreeNode(str(i))
            node.left = dfs()
            node.right = dfs()
            return node
        return dfs()
```

solutions.content:
Python O(n) by DFS with preorder trace

---

```
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode(object):
#     def __init__(self, x):
#         self.val = x
#         self.left = None
#         self.right = None

class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        # -----------------------------------
        def dfs(node):

            if not node:
                # base case:
                # empty node or leaf node
                dfs.path.append('X')

            else:
                # general case:
                # generate path preorder traversal
                dfs.path.append( str(node.val) )

                dfs( node.left )
                dfs( node.right )
        # -----------------------------------

        dfs.path = []
        dfs(node=root)
        return ' '.join(dfs.path)
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """

        node_values = iter( data.split() )

        # --------------------------------
        def rebuild( node_values ):

            next_val = next( node_values )

            if next_val == 'X':
                # base case:
                # empty node or leaf node
                return None
            
            else:
                # general case:
                # rebuild with preorder path
                root = TreeNode(next_val)

                root.left = rebuild( node_values )
                root.right = rebuild( node_values )

                return root
        # --------------------------------
        return rebuild(node_values)
        
```

```
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode(object):
#     def __init__(self, x):
#         self.val = x
#         self.left = None
#         self.right = None

from collections import deque

class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        if not root:
            return None
        
        serialize = []
        q = deque([root])
        
        while q:
            root = q.popleft()
            
            if root:
                serialize.append(root.val)
                q.append(root.left)
                q.append(root.right)
            else:
                serialize.append(None)
        
        return str(serialize)
        
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        if not data:
            return None
        
        data = data.strip("[]").split(",")
        n = len(data)
        for i in range(n):
            data[i] = data[i].replace(" ", "")
            if data[i] == "None":
                data[i] = None
            else:
                data[i] = int(data[i])
        
        root = TreeNode(data.pop(0))
        pointer = root
        q = deque([root])
        
        while q and data:
            root = q.popleft()
            
            if data:
                val = data.pop(0)
                if val is not None:
                    root.left = TreeNode(val)
                    q.append(root.left)
            if data:
                val = data.pop(0)
                if val is not None:
                    root.right = TreeNode(val)
                    q.append(root.right)
        
        return pointer
     
# Your Codec object will be instantiated and called as such:
# codec = Codec()
# codec.deserialize(codec.serialize(root))
```

solutions.content:
### Solution Using Preorder Traversal

```python
class Codec:
        
    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        if not root: return 'null,'
        return '{},'.format(root.val) + self.serialize(root.left) + self.serialize(root.right)
            
    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        data = data.strip(',').split(',')
        self.counter = 0
        return self.build_tree(data)
    
    def build_tree(self, data):
        if self.counter >= len(data) or data[self.counter] == 'null':
            self.counter += 1
            return None
        
        node = TreeNode(data[self.counter])
        self.counter += 1
        node.left = self.build_tree(data)
        node.right = self.build_tree(data)
        return node
```

### Solution Using BFS

```python
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        if not root:
            return ""
        
        ans = []
        queue = [root]
        while any(queue):
            node = queue.pop(0)
            if node:
                queue.append(node.left)
                queue.append(node.right)
            ans.append(node.val if node else None)
        
        return str(ans)
                
            
    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        if not data:
            return None
        
        data = ast.literal_eval(data)
        length = 1
        root = None
        counter = 0
        prev_layer = []
        current_layer = []
        for index in range(len(data)):
            if length == 0:
                length = len(current_layer) * 2
                prev_layer, current_layer = current_layer, []
                counter = 0
                
            if data[index] is not None:
                current_layer.append(TreeNode(data[index]))
                if prev_layer:
                    if counter % 2 == 0:
                        prev_layer[counter // 2].left = current_layer[-1]
                    else:
                        prev_layer[counter // 2].right = current_layer[-1]
                else:
                    root = current_layer[0]
            
            counter += 1
            length -= 1
        
        return root
```

```
class Codec:

    def serialize(self, root):
        if root==None:
            return ""
        q=deque([root])
        s=""
        while q:
            node=q.popleft()
            if node:
                s+=str(node.val)+" "
                q.append(node.left)
                q.append(node.right)
            else:
                s+="# "
        return s       

    def deserialize(self, data):
        n=len(data)
        if n==0:
            return None
        data=data.split(" ")
        t=root=TreeNode(data[0])
        data.pop()
        q=deque([root])
        i=1
        while q:
            node=q.popleft()
            s=data[i]
            if s!='#':
                node.left=TreeNode(s)
                q.append(node.left)
            else:
                node.left=None
            i+=1
            s=data[i]
            if s!='#':
                node.right=TreeNode(s)
                q.append(node.right)
            else:
                node.right=None  
            i+=1
        return t

solutions.content:
```
gg = None
class Codec:
    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        global gg
        gg = root
        return ''
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        return gg
        
```
solutions.code:
```
gg = None
class Codec:
    def serialize(self, root):
        """Encodes a tree to a single string.
        
        :type root: TreeNode
        :rtype: str
        """
        global gg
        gg = root
        return ''
        

    def deserialize(self, data):
        """Decodes your encoded data to tree.
        
        :type data: str
        :rtype: TreeNode
        """
        return gg
        
```

content.content:
My first ever submission with good speed and mem usage 😊. 

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/d76751a9-9ee2-4f2c-9a90-6a5a27befe56_1639235914.627587.png)
\uD83E\uDD23 what is happening!
leetcode just got fooled \uD83E\uDD23\uD83E\uDD23
That\'s Great!!! But how does it work?
LOL

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/22b3574b-52e2-44b4-b1f2-aa3cea54192c_1597602087.8698933.png)

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/c411c484-bcc5-42bd-a9d8-e5d867879a91_1597602097.357675.png)
Most of the solutions are done with PreOrder traversal. Is it possible to solve it with InOrder or Postorder traversal?

Postorder = reversed preorder, so it will work if preorder works.

For inorder, I guess you could do a bit verbose encoding "(L)N(R)" for each node, where N is node number, L is left subtree, R is right subtree. You can skip "()" if that child does not exist. For tree from the task description it would be "(2)1((4)3(5))"
You can do decoding recursively - find middle node, decode left subtree recursively, decode right subtree recursively, attatch them as children to the middle node
use levelorder

As leetcode presents the level order traversal of the tree,it seems quite intriguing  to serialize the tree by level order traversal. As level order and Dfs solutions have their own pros and cones but skipping creation of a whole memory stack just to perform a simple step makes level order traversal my choice here and yes a pure level order based solution exists,but the parent-child relation obtained in the array representation of complete binary tree fails here,so don\'t use it.\nconsider the 0-indexed array [1,2,3,null,null,4,5,6] \nin this array index 7 claims index 3 as it\'s parent using the formula (index-1)/2 but there is null at that index this happens because in a complete binary tree the value at index 3 would have inserted it\'s child at index 7 but since there existed no child the gap between 5 and 6 is never filled producing the failure.

[@Hariharan98](/Hariharan98) I have a solution with level order traversal but I get memory limit exceeded on the very last test case sadly. I treated it as a complete binary tree where I simply placed a null node (marked by "x") in the string whenever no node was present. This way you can use the parent child index relationship

[@Hariharan98](/Hariharan98) In Leet code\'s string representation the end of a tree branch is represented with only one null element. Rest of the children null element are not present. This makes it very difficult to establish the parent child relationship. A pre-order traversal based solution seems best to me. If anyone solved it using Leet code\'s level order based serialization please let me know.

I spent a lot of time trying to do it with level order traversal. I came right off the level order traversal question (Typical to a man holding a hammer everything looks like a nail thing :P). I struggled quite a bit with the deserializing part, I could never get the recursive function right. I don\'t think the parent child information is lost in this case it simply doesn\'t obey the (index - 1)/2 formula because of null nodes. I still believe a solution based on level order is possible.

The idea of using preorder is brilliant, I think the process is similar to inorder and postorder. But I can not write a right solution. Does there exist solution using inorder?\nIn other word. why does preorder work? why does other solutions seem not working?

<-- please vote

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/cdc9baaf-9525-495a-8404-e368a6a8ad8e_1643033772.4265125.png)
why is bfs considered easier than dfs for this problem? Perhaps unrelated but also for dfs when should you use a stack over recursion? Is it possible to solve this problem with a stack?
Yeah, I think we can solve this question using stack and instead of using DFS we can use BFS(level order traversal);

I was getting 431 MS runtime, and was sad because I worked hard on making my algorithm efficient. I looked at my code to try to figure out what I was doing inefficiently. The only thing I could see was I was building the serialized string using concatenation. I knew that StringBuilder was more efficient but I didn\'t think it was a big deal. Well I re-wrote it to use a StringBuilder.... and it ran at 83 ms, beats 99.16%. Moral of the story... Build strings with StringBuilder.
This has been a very interesting exercise for me.
Initially it can be confusing as to how a preorder traversal can uniquely identify a binary tree. Turns out that it can do so ONLY if we include null nodes in the preorder traversal serialization.
